member.name: T:Neovolve.Toolkit.Communication.Security.PasswordServiceCredentials
member.summary: The class provides a username password security implementation for WCF services. It will generate a containing a that exposes the password of the client credentials.

remarks.para: adds a custom to the service that creates a and for the service security context. The new principal is available via ServiceSecurityContext.PrimaryIdentity. The is also available via Thread.CurrentPrincipal if UserNamePasswordValidationMode in configuration is set to custom (see example below).
remarks.note: The instance is created using null for the roles of the principal.
remarks.para:
The is configured with the following:
Set type to the class in the serviceCredentials element.
Set userNamePasswordValidationMode to Custom in the userNameAuthentication element to use custom authentication rather than Windows authentication.
Set principalPermissionMode to Custom in the serviceAuthorization element to assign to Thread.CurrentPrincipal.
Set the customUserNamePasswordValidatorType in the userNameAuthentication element as required.
remarks.note: The is used if no customUserNamePasswordValidatorType is configured.
remarks.para: WCF enforces protection of the password in transmission using transport security. The security mode should be set to TransportWithMessageCredentials with a message client credential type as UserName.

example.code: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?> <configuration> <system.serviceModel> <bindings> <netTcpBinding> <binding name="netTcpBindingConfig"> <security mode="TransportWithMessageCredential"> <message clientCredentialType="UserName"/> </security> </binding> </netTcpBinding> </bindings> <services> <service behaviorConfiguration="Neovolve.Toolkit.Communication.SecurityTest.Service1Behavior" name="Neovolve.Toolkit.Communication.SecurityHost.Service1"> <endpoint address="net.tcp://localhost:8792/PasswordSecurityTest" binding="netTcpBinding" bindingConfiguration="netTcpBindingConfig" contract="Neovolve.Toolkit.Communication.SecurityHost.IService1"/> </service> </services> <behaviors> <serviceBehaviors> <behavior name="Neovolve.Toolkit.Communication.SecurityTest.Service1Behavior"> <serviceDebug includeExceptionDetailInFaults="true"/> <serviceCredentials type="Neovolve.Toolkit.Communication.Security.PasswordServiceCredentials, Neovolve.Toolkit.Communication.Security"> <serviceCertificate findValue="localhost" x509FindType="FindBySubjectName"/> <userNameAuthentication userNamePasswordValidationMode="Custom" customUserNamePasswordValidatorType="Neovolve.Toolkit.Communication.Security.OptionalPasswordValidator, Neovolve.Toolkit.Communication.Security"/> </serviceCredentials> <serviceAuthorization principalPermissionMode="Custom"/> </behavior> </serviceBehaviors> </behaviors> </system.serviceModel> </configuration>

member.name: M:Neovolve.Toolkit.Extensions.GetFormatMaskCount(System.String)
member.summary: Gets the count of format mask arguments supported by the specified string.

remarks.para: This method determines the maximum number of format arguments supported in a format string. The calculation of format mask index values supports the composite format string syntax described in the MSDN documentation.

The logic in this method will skip any format masks that are missing in order to determine the maximum count of arguments supported by the string. A value of "Pre{0}Post" will return 1 whereas "Pre{0} {5}Post" will return 6.

member.name: M:Neovolve.Toolkit.Extensions.FormatNullMasks(System.String,System.IFormatProvider,System.Object[])
member.summary: Formats the string using the value of {null} for any arguments that are either null or not provided.
member.param: The arguments used to format the string.
member.remarks: This method does not require that the number of arguments is the same or greater than the maximum format mask index. Any format argument not provided, or provided as a null value will be injected into the result string as the value {null}.

member.name: T:Neovolve.Toolkit.Threading.LockReader
member.summary: The class is used to provide thread safe read access to a resource using a provided or instance.

remarks.para:
is recommended for use instead of
.
has simplified lock recursion rules and is less likely to result in deadlock scenarios.
remarks.note:
The
and
classes encapsulate the logic of requesting, entering and exiting locks using the provided lock reference. Lock references (
and
) provided to these classes should not have their release/exit lock methods manually invoked in user code as they maintain their own internal lock counters.
and
will release their relevant locks when they are disposed. See the example below for incorrect usage of these classes.
remarks.para:
Calling
manually is supported but not recommended. The
/
knows internally that it is already disposed and won't release the lock again. In this situation, the code between the Dispose() and the instance going out of scope will not be protected with the lock obtained by that instance.

Never invoke the lock release/exit methods on the lock reference directly. In this case,
and
are not aware that the lock has already been released and will attempt to release the lock when it is disposed. Where recursive locks are obtained, this may not have a great affect, but debugging locking problems will become difficult. Greater risk is encountered where the first lock in a recursive chain is released by a child lock as per the incorrect usage example below.

The
and
classes are best used with a using statement. The using statement ensures that the
and
instances are disposed and exit their relevant locks even when exceptions are encountered. Manually disposing of
and
instances is supported, but the locks held will be released. The using statement also provides a syntax to easily understand the scope of a lock.

example.para:
This example demonstrates how to use
and
with a
lock instance to read and write to a resource in a thread safe manner. This example also shows how a read lock can be upgraded to write lock.

This example demonstrates how to use
and
with a
lock instance to read and write to a resource in a thread safe manner. This example also shows how a read lock can be upgraded to write lock.

The following code shows the incorrect usage of
and
. The code manually releases a lock external to
which requested the lock.

member.name: M:Neovolve.Toolkit.Threading.LockReader.#ctor(System.Threading.ReaderWriterLockSlim)

overloads.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class using the provided lock reference.

remarks.para: This constructor acquires a read lock that is not upgradeable to a write lock.

Unlike
, usage of a
instance must explicitly indicate whether a standard read lock or an upgradeable read lock is requested. Only an upgradeable read lock can be upgraded to a write lock. See
for further information.
As no timeout value is supplied, this call will block indefinitely until the lock is entered.

member.exception:
No
was provided.

The
property is
and the current thread has already entered the lock.

member.name: T:Neovolve.Toolkit.Communication.ErrorHandlerAttribute
member.summary: The class is used to decorate WCF service implementations with a that identifies references to invoke when the service encounters errors.

remarks.para: implementations are often set up for services using configuration. This may create risks in cases where configuration is not correctly defined or configuration values are missing. The result of this may be that exception shielding and error handling are not functioning as intended.

Lack of exception shielding may be a security risk because exception information crosses the service boundary that was not intended. The details of the exception may contain sensitive information that the consumers of the services should not be able to read.

Lack of error handling may not be a security risk, but will produce an unexpected behaviour for clients as they consume the service. According to the contract, the client may expect to see a particular fault exception being raised, but may instead receive a different fault.
remarks.note: The constructor overloads that accept a params array are not CLS compliant. Usage of attributes that use array arguments breaks CLS compliance. These methods have been appropriately marked as not being CLS compliant.
remarks.para: The constructor of the attribute instance either takes a single type or string, or a params array of strings or types. This allows for a single error handler to be assigned in a CLS compliant way, or multiple error handlers to be assigned in a non-CLS compliant way.

member.name: T:Neovolve.Toolkit.Threading.LockWriter
member.summary: The class is used to provide thread safe write access to a resource using a provided or instance.

remarks.para:
is recommended for use instead of
.
has simplified lock recursion rules and is less likely to result in deadlock scenarios.
remarks.note:
The
and
classes encapsulate the logic of requesting, entering and exiting locks using the provided lock reference. Lock references (
and
) provided to these classes should not have their release/exit lock methods manually invoked in user code as they maintain their own internal lock counters.
and
will release their relevant locks when they are disposed. See the example below for incorrect usage of these classes.
remarks.para:
Calling
manually is supported but not recommended. The
/
knows internally that it is already disposed and won't release the lock again. In this situation, the code between the Dispose() and the instance going out of scope will not be protected with the lock obtained by that instance.

Never invoke the lock release/exit methods on the lock reference directly. In this case,
and
are not aware that the lock has already been released and will attempt to release the lock when it is disposed. Where recursive locks are obtained, this may not have a great affect, but debugging locking problems will become difficult. Greater risk is encountered where the first lock in a recursive chain is released by a child lock as per the incorrect usage example below.

The
and
classes are best used with a using statement. The using statement ensures that the
and
instances are disposed and exit their relevant locks even when exceptions are encountered. Manually disposing of
and
instances is supported, but the locks held will be released. The using statement also provides a syntax to easily understand the scope of a lock.

example.para:
This example demonstrates how to use
and
with a
lock instance to read and write to a resource in a thread safe manner. This example also shows how a read lock can be upgraded to write lock.

This example demonstrates how to use
and
with a
lock instance to read and write to a resource in a thread safe manner. This example also shows how a read lock can be upgraded to write lock.

The following code shows the incorrect usage of
and
. The code manually releases a lock external to
which requested the lock.

member.name: T:Neovolve.Toolkit.Communication.ChannelProxyHandler`1
member.summary: The class is used to provide a proxy implementation for a WCF service channel.
member.typeparam: The type of WCF service to invoke.

remarks.para: The ensures that the the WCF call will always operate on a valid WCF channel. The proxy handler will recreate the WCF channel if a prior call has faulted the channel.
remarks.note: The proxy handler will throw all WCF exceptions to the caller even though it manages faulted channels internally.
remarks.para: The default constructor will search the application configuration for an endpoint for the specified service contract. A will be thrown if no endpoint configuration is found or if multiple endpoint configurations are found.
The WCF channel is closed when the proxy is disposed.

Any initialization required for the WCF channel can be achieved by providing a of type to the method. This action will be invoked before each time the WCF channel is created. Any existing channel will be destroyed when an action is defined to ensure that the next channel invocation uses the provided initialization functionality.
